title: Michigan 38, Northwestern 0: Wolverines stomp Wildcats
text:
Michigan 38, Northwestern 0: Wolverines stomp Wildcats Michigan earns its third consecutive shutout Post to Facebook Michigan 38, Northwestern 0: Wolverines stomp Wildcats Michigan earns its third consecutive shutout Check out this story on Freep.com: http://on.freep.com/1RAmam7 Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 95 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Michigan 38, Northwestern 0: Wolverines stomp Wildcats Mark Snyder, Detroit Free Press 7:39 p.m. EDT October 10, 2015 Michigan coach Jim Harbaugh talks about his team's 38-0 win over Northwestern. Video by Mark Snyder / DFP Oct 10, 2015; Ann Arbor, MI, USA; Michigan Wolverines wide receiver Jehu Chesson (86) runs back the opening kick off for a touchdown against the Northwestern Wildcats at Michigan Stadium. (Photo: Rick Osentoski, USA TODAY Sports) 
As the Michigan football machine has rolled the past few weeks, there was always a caveat. 
What about against a team that’s not tired from traveling cross country? What about one without a high school coach? Or one about to get fired? 
On Saturday, it was: what about an elite defense and one that is ranked in the Top 15. 
These may be mere footnotes by the end of the season, as the No. 18 Wolverines made a definitive statement Saturday, whipping No. 13 Northwestern, 38-0, at Michigan Stadium before and announced attendance of 110,452. 
The game launched Michigan’s stellar defense into historic territory with its third straight shutout, the first time for the program since 1980. 
As with the win over BYU two weeks earlier, the Wolverines took control in the first half and put it on offensive cruise control in the second. 
It only took 13 seconds for U-M (5-1, 2-0 Big Ten) to provide an answer, as Jehu Chesson took the opening kickoff back 96 yards for a touchdown. 
From there, the Wolverines did whatever they wanted. 
The next two drives were quick, effective marches, each under four minutes, with the Wolverines toying with the nation’s No. 1 scoring defense. 
On the first offensive drive, a 32-yard Jake Butt catch and one-yard Drake Johnson run gave the Wolverines their first offensive score, pushing the margin to 14-0. Michigan QB Jake Rudock falls into he end zone on a short run for a touchdown late in the first quarter of the 38-0 win over Northwestern Saturday in Ann Arbor. Julian H. Gonzalez DFP Michigan's Drake Johnson jump onto top of the pile and crosses the goal line for their second touchdown in the first quarter of the 38-0 win over Northwestern Saturday in Ann Arbor.
